column4: There is a program or utility that will list major files for you............ but it escapes me at the moment.
you go to the directory and do sudo apt-get rm <filenametoremove>
why is apt-get needed for folder removal??
good question. It all depends really on the permissions the dl program/pgk has.
when you dl a debian package I believe it comes with permissions that only allow the su to ex, read, write, etc.
if you change the permissions to give users free reign, then you can probably remove the original file/package without using sudo
yes, but apt-get isn't needed to rm a directory.
so why not just: rm -r folder-or-filname-here
you ca dual boot, you will just choose between the kernels at bootup which defines the release
if it is ext based filesystem, you can use partimage
Ok. Which I can run from within Ubuntu, right? No need to have a separate boot CD or anything?
if the partition can be unmounted then it can be used
Ok, yes, it can be. It's an entire drive - separate from the OS drive, etc. Ok, thanks.
could use rsync. If the partition is a system partition which you are booted to, you will need to use a liveCD
